soln_description:
## Solution.

By grouping conveniently and applying transformation formulas, we simplify the base on the left side of the equation.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\sin 1 + \sin 3 + \sin 5 + \sin 7}{\cos 1 + \cos 3 + \cos 5 + \cos 7} = \\
= & \frac{(\sin 1 + \sin 7) + (\sin 3 + \sin 5)}{(\cos 1 + \cos 7) + (\cos 3 + \cos 5)} = \\
= & \frac{2 \sin \frac{1+7}{2} \cos \frac{1-7}{2} + 2 \sin \frac{3+5}{2} \cos \frac{3-5}{2}}{2 \cos \frac{1+7}{2} \cos \frac{1-7}{2} + 2 \cos \frac{3+5}{2} \cos \frac{3-5}{2}} = \\
= & \frac{2 \sin 4 \cos 3 + 2 \sin 4 \cos 1}{2 \cos 4 \cos 3 + 2 \cos 4 \cos 1} = \\
= & \frac{2 \sin 4 (\cos 3 + \cos 1)}{2 \cos 4 (\cos 3 + \cos 1)} = \tan 4.
\end{aligned}
$$

The given equation transforms into

$$
(\tan 4)^{\frac{1}{19 x} - 107} = \frac{1}{\tan 4}
$$

It follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{19 x} - 107 = -1 \\
& \frac{1}{19 x} = 106 \\
& 2014 x = 1 \\
& x = \frac{1}{2014}
\end{aligned}
$$
informal_statement:
Task B-3.6. Solve the equation

$$
\left(\frac{\sin 1+\sin 3+\sin 5+\sin 7}{\cos 1+\cos 3+\cos 5+\cos 7}\right)^{\frac{1}{19 x}-107}=\frac{1}{\tan 4}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

/- Task B-3.6. Solve the equation

$$
\left(\frac{\sin 1+\sin 3+\sin 5+\sin 7}{\cos 1+\cos 3+\cos 5+\cos 7}\right)^{\frac{1}{19 x}-107}=\frac{1}{\tan 4}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_246613 {x : ℝ} (hx : x ≠ 0) :
    ((sin 1 + sin 3 + sin 5 + sin 7) / (cos 1 + cos 3 + cos 5 + cos 7))^(1 / (19 * x) - 107) =
    1 / tan 4 ↔ x = 1 / 2014 := by

soln_description: The shortest period is the smallest d such that p divides 10 d - 1. [We know, for example, that p divides 10 p-1 - 1, so such d exists, but that line of thought does not lead anywhere.] Let p be a prime and let N p = 10 2p + 10 p + 1. Obviously N p = 3 mod 9, so N p is divisible by 3 but not 9. So take q to be a prime dividing N p /3. We have just established that q is not 3. Now 10 3p - 1 = N p (10 p - 1), so q divides 10 3p - 1. Hence the shortest period d for q must divide 3p. So it must be 1, 3, p or 3p. It cannot be 1 for then q would divide 10 - 1 = 9 and we have shown that q is not 3. It cannot be p, for then N p = 1 + 1 + 1 = 3 mod q, whereas we are assuming that q divides N p . If it is 3, then q divides 10 3 - 1 = 3 3 37 and so q = 37. Now we claim that we can always choose q to be a prime other than 37. If this were not true then we would have N p = 3.37 k . But then N p = 3 mod 4, whereas N p = 1 mod 4. So d must be 3p. Thus by letting p run through the primes, we get a sequence of primes q with shortest period 3p. Each prime q must be distinct, since each has a distinct shortest period. So we get infinitely many primes q with shortest period a multiple of 3. Suppose 1/q = 0.a 1 a 2 a 3 ... with shortest period 3p. Then b j = 0.a j a j+1 a j+2 ... is the fractional part of 10 j- 1 /q. Obviously a j < 10 b j , so a j + a j+p + a j+2p < 10(b j + b j+p + b j+2p ) = (1/q) (10 j + 10 j+p + 10 j+2p = 10 j N p /q. But N p /q is an integer, so 10(b j + b j+p + b j+2p ) is a multiple of 10. Each b i < 1, so 10(b j + b j+p + b j+2p ) ≤ 20 and hence a j + a j+p + a j+2p ≤ 19. But 19 can be achieved, as illustrated by the case 1/7. 40th IMO shortlist 1999 © John Scholes jscholes@kalva.demon.co.uk 10 Oct 2002
informal_statement: 40th IMO 1999 shortlist Problem N4 Show that there are infinitely many primes p such that 1/p has its shortest period divisible by 3: 1/p = 0.a 1 a 2 ... a 3k a 1 a 2 ... . Amongst such primes find the largest possible value for a i + a i+k + a i+2k . For example, 1/7 = 0.142857... So the possible values for p = 7 are 1+2+5 = 8 and 4+8+7 = 19.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- 40th IMO 1999 shortlist Problem N4 Show that there are infinitely many primes p such that 1/p has its shortest period divisible by 3: 1/p = 0.a 1 a 2 ... a 3k a 1 a 2 ... . Amongst such primes find the largest possible value for a i + a i+k + a i+2k . For example, 1/7 = 0.142857... So the possible values for p = 7 are 1+2+5 = 8 and 4+8+7 = 19. -/
theorem number_theory_135292 :
  IsGreatest {x | ∃ p : ℕ, Nat.Prime p ∧ x = (Nat.floor (10^p / p)) % 10 + (Nat.floor (10^p / p + 1)) % 10 + (Nat.floor (10^p / p + 2)) % 10} 19 := by

soln_description:
Task 2. There are a total of 15 stations: 4 new ones and 11 old ones.

The throughput capacity of the old stations is 11 x $200=2200$ vehicles per day, and for the new ones: $200+700=900$ vehicles per day. In total, the stations can refuel: $2200+900=3100$ vehicles per day.

Vehicles from the city fleet account for only $70 \%$ of all vehicles refueled at the CNG stations in St. Petersburg, so $3100 x 0.7=2170$ vehicles can be refueled. Currently, there are 1000 vehicles in the city fleet, so the city fleet of gas-powered vehicles can be increased by 1170 units.
informal_statement: Task 2. By how many units can the city's fleet of natural gas vehicles be increased in 2022, assuming that the capacity of each of the old CNG stations in the city is equal to the capacity of the new station on Narodnaya Street, and that the city's fleet constitutes only $70 \%$ of all vehicles refueling at CNG stations in St. Petersburg. Assume that the stations are used at $100 \%$ of their capacity.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Task 2. By how many units can the city's fleet of natural gas vehicles be increased in 2022, assuming that the capacity of each of the old CNG stations in the city is equal to the capacity of the new station on Narodnaya Street, and that the city's fleet constitutes only $70 \%$ of all vehicles refueling at CNG stations in St. Petersburg. Assume that the stations are used at $100 \%$ of their capacity. -/
theorem algebra_213221 (x : ℕ) (hx : x > 0) (h : (100 / 100 : ℝ) * x = (70 / 100 : ℝ) * (x + y)) :
    y = 1170 := by

informal_statement: Given that $a$ and $b$ are positive real numbers and satisfy the equations ${{a}^{2}}-{{b}^{2}}=128$ and $a=8-b$, find the value of $b-a$.
informal_proof:
We are given two real numbers, $a$ and $b$, along with the following four hypotheses:
1. $h_0: 0 < a$
2. $h_1: 0 < b$
3. $h_2: a^2 - b^2 = 128$
4. $h_3: a = 8 - b$

Our goal is to prove that $b - a = -16$.

The proof begins by substituting the expression for $a$ from hypothesis $h_3$ into hypothesis $h_2$. This replaces $a$ in the equation $a^2 - b^2 = 128$ with $(8 - b)$, yielding a new equation that depends only on the variable $b$:
$$(8 - b)^2 - b^2 = 128$$

Next, we proceed with algebraic simplification to solve for $b$. First, we expand the squared term $(8 - b)^2$:
$$(64 - 16b + b^2) - b^2 = 128$$

The $b^2$ terms cancel each other out, which simplifies the equation to a linear one:
$$64 - 16b = 128$$

To isolate the term with $b$, we subtract 64 from both sides:
$$-16b = 128 - 64$$
$$-16b = 64$$

Finally, we divide by -16 to find the value of $b$:
$$b = \frac{64}{-16} = -4$$

The derivation from hypotheses $h_2$ and $h_3$ leads to the conclusion that $b = -4$. However, this result is in direct contradiction with hypothesis $h_1$, which states that $b$ must be positive ($0 < b$).

Since the given set of hypotheses leads to a logical contradiction ($0 < -4$ is false), the premises are inconsistent. In classical logic, any proposition can be proven from a contradiction (this is the principle of explosion, or *ex falso quodlibet*). Therefore, the conclusion $b - a = -16$ is a logical consequence of the contradictory hypotheses.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Given that $a$ and $b$ are positive real numbers and satisfy the equations ${{a}^{2}}-{{b}^{2}}=128$ and $a=8-b$, find the value of $b-a$. -/
theorem algebra_6851
    (a b : ℝ)
    (h₀ : 0 < a)
    (h₁ : 0 < b)
    (h₂ : a ^ 2 - b ^ 2 = 128)
    (h₃ : a = 8 - b) :
    b - a = -16 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_6851
    (a b : ℝ)
    (h₀ : 0 < a)
    (h₁ : 0 < b)
    (h₂ : a ^ 2 - b ^ 2 = 128)
    (h₃ : a = 8 - b) :
    b - a = -16 := by 
  rw [h₃] at h₂
  nlinarith

soln_description:
First, we have

$$
\sum_{k=2}^{n} a_{k}=\sum_{k=2}^{n}\left(\frac{1}{p_{1}}+\frac{1}{p_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{p_{n}}\right)=\sum_{p \leqslant n} \frac{1}{p}\left[\frac{n}{p}\right]
$$

where the last sum is taken over the primes $p$ and $[\cdot]$ denotes the floor function. Furthermore,

$$
\sum_{p \leqslant n} \frac{1}{p}\left[\frac{n}{p}\right] \leqslant \sum_{p \leqslant n} \frac{n}{p^{2}}<n\left(\frac{1}{4}+\sum_{k=1}^{[n / 2]} \frac{1}{(2 k+1)^{2}}\right)<\frac{n}{4}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{[n / 2]} \frac{1}{k(k+1)}\right)=\frac{n}{4}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{[n / 2]} \frac{1}{k}-\frac{1}{k+1}\right)<\frac{n}{2}
$$

consequently $\sum_{k=2}^{n} a_{k}<\frac{n}{2}$ for all $n \geqslant 2$. Now, by the arithmetic-geometric mean inequality,

$$
a_{2} a_{3} \cdots a_{n}<\left(\frac{a_{2}+a_{3}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n-1}\right)^{n-1}<\frac{1}{2^{n-1}}\left(1+\frac{1}{n-1}\right)^{n-1}
$$

and by expanding using the binomial formula, we find

$$
\left(1+\frac{1}{n-1}\right)^{n-1} \leqslant \sum_{k=0}^{n-1} \frac{1}{k!} \leqslant 1+\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} \frac{1}{2^{k}} \leqslant 3
$$

hence $a_{2} a_{3} \cdots a_{n}<\frac{3}{2^{n-1}}$. By summing these inequalities, we have

$$
\sum_{n=2}^{\infty} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}<\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{6}+\frac{1}{12}+\frac{1}{60}+3\left(\frac{1}{2^{5}}+\frac{1}{2^{6}}+\cdots\right)=\frac{46}{60}+\frac{3}{2^{5}}\left(1+\frac{1}{2}+\cdots\right)=\frac{46}{60}+\frac{6}{32}<1
$$
informal_statement:
. If $p_{1}, \ldots, p_{k}$ are the prime divisors of an integer $n$, we set $a_{n}=\frac{1}{p_{1}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{p_{k}}$. Show that for any integer $N \geqslant 2$ :

$$
\sum_{n=2}^{N} a_{2} a_{3} \cdots a_{n}<1
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- . If $p_{1}, \ldots, p_{k}$ are the prime divisors of an integer $n$, we set $a_{n}=\frac{1}{p_{1}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{p_{k}}$. Show that for any integer $N \geqslant 2$ :

$$
\sum_{n=2}^{N} a_{2} a_{3} \cdots a_{n}<1
$$ -/
theorem number_theory_154079 (a : ℕ → ℝ)
  (ha : ∀ n, a n = ∑ p in n.primeFactors, (1 : ℝ)/p) :
  ∀ N ≥ 2, ∑ n in Finset.Icc 2 N, ∏ i in Finset.Icc 2 n, a i < 1 :=

soln_description:
Let's write the Euclidean division of $n$ by $m: n=q m+r$. Now we want to perform the Euclidean division of $2^{n}-1$ by $2^{m}-1$:

$$
2^{n}-1=\left(2^{m q}-1\right) 2^{r}+2^{r}-1=\left(2^{m}-1\right)\left(1+2^{m}+2^{2 m}+\cdots+2^{(q-1) m}\right)+2^{r}-1
$$

Moreover, $2^{r}-1<2^{m}-1$. Thus, the Euclidean algorithm associated with $2^{n}-1$ and $2^{m}-1$ can be performed in parallel with that of $n$ and $m$. If $d=n \wedge m$, we will have

$$
2^{m}-1 \wedge 2^{n}-1=2^{d}-1
$$

The theorem of Bézout: the last game we will play consists once again in retracing the Euclidean algorithm, in the manner of what we did at the end of the previous proof. We know that

$$
d=r_{l}=r_{l-2}-r_{l-1} q_{l-1}=r_{l-2} u_{1}+r_{l-1} v_{1}
$$

We then replace $r_{l-1}$ by its value given by the previous line:

$$
r_{l}=r_{l-2}-\left(r_{l-3}-r_{l-2} q_{l-2}\right) q_{l-1}=r_{l-3}\left(-q_{l-1}\right)+r_{l-2}\left(1+q_{l-2} q_{l-1}\right)=r_{l-3} u_{2}+r_{l-2} v_{2}
$$

And so on, at each step, we find two integers (relative) $\mathfrak{u}_{\mathrm{k}}$ and $v_{\mathrm{k}}$ such that $\mathrm{d}=$ $r_{l-k-1} u_{k}+r_{l-k} v_{k}$. Thus, at the end, we obtain two relative integers $u$ and $v$ such that $d=u r_{0}+v r_{1}$.

We have just shown half of the famous theorem of Bézout: two integers $a$ and $b$ are coprime if and only if there exist two relative integers $u$ and $v$ such that $1=a u+b v$.

Indeed, the fact that if $a \wedge b=1$ then there exist $u$ and $v$ comes from the analysis made below when $d=1$. The converse must now be easy. If there exist $u$ and $v$ such that $1=a u+b v$, and if $d$ divides $a$ and $b$, then it divides $a u+b v$ so $d=1$.
informal_statement:
Determine $2^{m}-1 \wedge 2^{n}-1$.

Translate the text above into English, please keep the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Determine $2^{m}-1 \wedge 2^{n}-1$.

Translate the text above into English, please keep the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly. -/
theorem number_theory_150800 (m n : ℕ) :
    Nat.gcd (2 ^ m - 1) (2 ^ n - 1) = 2 ^ (Nat.gcd m n) - 1 := by

soln_description:
5. A.

Since $q=m n=(a-1)(b-1)$ is an integer, and $p=m+n$ is an integer, therefore, $m$ and $n$ are the two rational roots of the equation $x^{2}-p x+q=0$.
Thus, $\Delta=p^{2}-4 q$ is a perfect square.
Solving the equation gives $m, n=\frac{p \pm \sqrt{p^{2}-4 q}}{2}$.
Since $p^{2}-4 q$ has the same parity as $p$, the numerator in the root expression is even.
Hence, $m$ and $n$ are both integers.
informal_statement:

$$
m=\frac{a^{2}-1}{b+1}, n=\frac{b^{2}-1}{a+1} \text {. }
$$

If $m+n$ is an integer, then the integer(s) among $m, n$ is(are) ).
(A) $m, n$
(B) $m$
(C) $n$
(D) none

import Mathlib

/- 5. Let $a, b$ be integers greater than 1,
$$
m=\frac{a^{2}-1}{b+1}, n=\frac{b^{2}-1}{a+1} \text {. }

If $m+n$ is an integer, then the integer(s) among $m, n$ is(are) ).
(A) $m, n$
(B) $m$
(C) $n$
(D) none -/
theorem algebra_304894 {a b : ℤ} (ha : a > 1) (hb : b > 1)
    (m n : ℚ) (hm : m = (a ^ 2 - 1) / (b + 1)) (hn : n = (b ^ 2 - 1) / (a + 1))
    (hmn : ∃ k : ℤ, m + n = k) :
    ∃ m' n' : ℤ, m' = m ∧ n' = n := by

soln_description:
(1) Let $2^{n}-1=a^{2}, a \in \mathbf{N}$, then $a$ is an odd number. Let $a=2 k+1$, we have
$$
2^{n}-(2 k+1)^{2}+1=4 k^{2}+4 k+2 \text{. }
$$

That is, $2^{n-1}=2 k^{2}+2 k+1$. Since $n>1$, the left side of this equation is even, while the right side is odd, leading to a contradiction.
(2) Let $2^{n}-1=a^{3}, a \in \mathbf{N}$, then $a$ is an odd number. Let $a=2 k+1$, we have $2^{n}=(2 k+1)^{3}+$ $1=(2 k+2)\left(4 k^{2}+2 k+1\right)$.
That is, $2^{n}$ has an odd factor $4 k^{2}+2 k+1$ greater than 1, which is impossible.
informal_statement: 19. 1. $23 * \star$ Let the natural number $n>1$, prove that $2^{n}-1$ is not the square of any integer, nor is it the cube of any integer.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 19. 1. $23 * \star$ Let the natural number $n>1$, prove that $2^{n}-1$ is not the square of any integer, nor is it the cube of any integer. -/
theorem number_theory_186700 (n : ℕ) (hn : n > 1) :
    ¬(∃ k, (2^n - 1) = k^2) ∧ ¬(∃ k, (2^n - 1) = k^3) := by

soln_description:
We want to prove that the solutions are of the form $g(n)=n+c$. We verify that these functions are solutions.

Lemma 45. Let $p$ be a prime such that $g(n) \equiv g(m) \bmod p$. Then $m \equiv n \bmod p$.

Proof. We seek $k$ such that $p \| g(n)+k$ (i.e., $p \mid g(n)+k$ and $p^{2} \nmid g(n)+k$) and $p \| g(m)+k$.

If $p>2$: Choose $k_{1}$ such that $p^{2} \mid g(n)+k_{1}$ and $k_{2}$ such that $p^{2} \mid g(m)+k_{2}$.

If $k_{1}+p \equiv k_{2} \bmod p^{2}$, choose $k=k_{1}+2 p$; otherwise, choose $k=k_{1}+p$.

If $p=2$:

- Case 1: $4 \mid g(n)-g(m)$, choose $k$ such that $2 \| g(n)+k$ and we will also have $2 \| g(m)+k$.
- Case 2: $2 \| g(n)-g(m)$. This is a special case (but it works the same way), we need to choose $k$ such that $8 \| g(n)+k$ and we will also have $2 \| g(m)+k$. Since $(g(n)+k)(g(k)+n)$ is a perfect square divisible by $p$, it is also divisible by $p^{2}$. And since $p \| g(n)+k, p \mid g(k n$ (in the special case, it works exactly the same way, with $p^{3}$ and $p^{4}$). Similarly, $p \mid g(k)+m$. Therefore, $p \mid n-m$.

If $g(m)=g(n)$, then for all $p$ prime, $p \mid m-n$, so $m=n$. Therefore, $g$ is injective.

We set $m=n+1$, we get $|g(n)-g(n+1)|=1$ for all $n$. Since it is injective, it must be monotonic. And since it takes values in $\mathbb{N}$, it must be increasing.

Therefore, $g(n)=n+c$.

Remark 46. If we find the lemma a bit too difficult to prove, we can very well manage without the case $p=2$.

## Order of an Element

Recall 47. Let $n \in \mathbb{N}$. Then for all $a$ coprime with $n$, $a^{\varphi(n)} \equiv 1 \bmod n$. In particular, if $n=p$ is prime, then $a^{p-1} \equiv 1 \bmod p$.
informal_statement:
(IMO 2010 Problem 3).

Find all $g: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}$ such that $(g(n)+m)(g(m)+n)$ is a perfect square for all $n, m$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- (IMO 2010 Problem 3).

Find all $g: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}$ such that $(g(n)+m)(g(m)+n)$ is a perfect square for all $n, m$. -/
theorem number_theory_141558 (g : ℕ → ℕ) :
    (∀ n m, IsSquare ((g n + m) * (g m + n))) ↔
    ∃ c, ∀ n, g n = c * n := by

soln_description:
Solution. All such sets are the set $\sqrt{\mathbb{N}}=\{\sqrt{n} \mid n \in \mathbb{N}\}$ and the sets $\sqrt{[n]}=\{\sqrt{k} \mid k \leqslant n, k \in \mathbb{N}\}$ for any $n \in \mathbb{N}$. It's easy to check that all such sets satisfy the problem's condition.

1 point.

We will now show that any $S$ that satisfies the two conditions of the problem is of this form. It suffices to show that $S$ can only contain square roots of positive integers and that $\sqrt{n} \in S$ implies that $\sqrt{m} \in S$ for any $m \leqslant n$.

First, note that we have $1 \in S$ so for any $x \in S$ with $x>1$ we have $\sqrt{x^{2}-1} \in S$. Repeated application of this gives that $\sqrt{x^{2}-n} \in S$ for any $n \in \mathbb{N}$ such that $n<x^{2}$.

3 points.

Now, assume that some number $x \in S$ is not the square root of an integer. We then immediately have $0<x^{2}-\left\lfloor x^{2}\right\rfloor<1$ as $x^{2}$ is not an integer, and the above consideration gives that $\sqrt{x^{2}-\left\lfloor x^{2}\right\rfloor} \in S$ and is strictly less than 1 , which is a contradiction with $1=\min (S)$. Therefore, we conclude that any element of $S$ has to be the square root of an integer.

5 points.

Now, take some $\sqrt{n} \in S$. The above consideration immediately gives $\sqrt{n-1} \in S$ and we can conclude by induction that any smaller square root of an integer must also be a member of $S$, and we are done.

1 point.

Notes on marking:

- Any proof that shows that the members of $S$ must necessarily be square roots of positive integers is worth 8 points. Of the other 2 points, one is assigned for correctly and completely writing the solution set, and one for noting that if $\sqrt{n} \in S$, then all smaller square roots $\sqrt{m}$ must also be in $S$. This must be explicitly commented on.
informal_statement:
Problem 1. Determine all sets of real numbers $S$ such that:

- 1 is the smallest element of $S$,
- for all $x, y \in S$ such that $x>y, \sqrt{x^{2}-y^{2}} \in S$.

(Adian Anibal Santos Sepčić)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Problem 1. Determine all sets of real numbers $S$ such that:

- 1 is the smallest element of $S$,
- for all $x, y \in S$ such that $x>y, \sqrt{x^{2}-y^{2}} \in S$.

(Adian Anibal Santos Sepčić) -/
theorem algebra_244039 {S : Set ℝ} (hS : 1 ∈ S)
  (hS' : ∀ x ∈ S, ∀ y ∈ S, x > y → sqrt (x^2 - y^2) ∈ S) :
  S = {x | 1 ≤ x} := by

import Mathlib

/- Prove that the system \begin{align*}
x^6+x^3+x^3y+y & = 147^{157} \\
x^3+x^3y+y^2+y+z^9 & = 157^{147}
\end{align*} has no solutions in integers $x$, $y$, and $z$. -/
theorem number_theory_46400 (x y z : ℤ) :
    x^6 + x^3 + x^3 * y + y ≠ 147^157 ∨
    x^3 + x^3 * y + y^2 + y + z^9 ≠ 157^147 := by

soln_description:
Let $b_{m}=a_{m}-(m+1)$ for all $m \geqslant k$. Note that $a_{m}$ is coprime with $m+1$ if and only if $a_{m}$ and $b_{m}$ are coprime, and if that is the case, $b_{m+1}=b_{m}$ and otherwise, $b_{m+1}=m$. Initially, we have $b_{k}=k-1 \geqslant 2$. By looking at the sequence, it seems that $b_{k}$ remains constant, then increases once, then remains constant, etc.

Fix an $m$ such that $a_{m}=2 m$, in this case we have $b_{m}=m-1$. Then we have $a_{m+i}=2 m+i=2(m-1)+2+i$ and $b_{m+i}=b_{m}=m-1$ until we have a term not coprime with $m-1$, that is, an $i$ such that $2+i$ and $m-1$ are not coprime. Thus, this happens for $0 \leqslant i \leqslant p_{m-1}-2$, where $p_{m-1}$ is the smallest prime factor of $m-1$. Then, since $p_{m-1}$ divides both $m-1=b_{m+p_{m-1}-2}$ and divides $a_{m+p_{m-1}-2}=2(m-1)+p_{m-1}$. Therefore, we have $a_{m+p_{m-1}-1}=2\left(m+p_{m-1}-1\right)$, and $a_{m+p_{m-1}-1}-a_{m+p_{m-1}-2}=2\left(m+p_{m-1}-1\right)-\left(2(m-1)+p_{m-1}\right)=p_{m-1}$.

Thus for each $m$ for which $a_{m}=2 m$, we can find $m^{\prime}>m$ such that $a_{m^{\prime}}-a_{m^{\prime}-1}$ is prime, and $a_{m^{\prime}}=2 m^{\prime}$. By immediate induction, we have an infinite number of $m^{\prime}$ such that $a_{m^{\prime}}-a_{m^{\prime}-1}$ is prime.
informal_statement: Let $k \geqslant 3$ be an integer. We define the sequence $\left(a_{n}\right)_{n \geqslant k}$ by $a_{k}=2 k$ and for $n \geqslant k, a_{n+1}=a_{n}+1$ if $a_{n}$ and $n+1$ are coprime, otherwise $a_{n+1}=2(n+1)$. Show that there are infinitely many $n$ such that $a_{n+1}-a_{n}$ is prime.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $k \geqslant 3$ be an integer. We define the sequence $\left(a_{n}\right)_{n \geqslant k}$ by $a_{k}=2 k$ and for $n \geqslant k, a_{n+1}=a_{n}+1$ if $a_{n}$ and $n+1$ are coprime, otherwise $a_{n+1}=2(n+1)$. Show that there are infinitely many $n$ such that $a_{n+1}-a_{n}$ is prime. -/
theorem number_theory_133677 (k : ℕ) (hk : 3 ≤ k) (a : ℕ → ℕ)
    (ha : a k = 2 * k) (h : ∀ n ≥ k, Nat.Coprime (a n) (n + 1) → a (n + 1) = a n + 1)
    (h' : ∀ n ≥ k, ¬Nat.Coprime (a n) (n + 1) → a (n + 1) = 2 * (n + 1)) :
    ∀ N, ∃ n, n > N ∧ Nat.Prime (a (n + 1) - a n) := by

soln_description: 6. $8 x-y-24=0$ Hint: Let $A(x, y)$, then $B(6-x,-y),\left\{\begin{array}{l}2 x-y-2=0, \\ (6-x)+(-y)+3=0,\end{array}\left\{\begin{array}{l}x=\frac{11}{3}, \\ y=\frac{16}{3}\end{array}\right.\right.$
informal_statement: 6. Draw a line through $P(3,0)$ such that the line segment $A B$ intercepted between the two lines $2 x-y-2=0$ and $x+y+3=0$ is exactly bisected by point $P$. Then the equation of this line is $\qquad$ .
informal_proof:
We are given four hypotheses for real numbers `x` and `y`:
1.  `h`: $x \neq 0$
2.  `h1`: $2x - y - 2 = 0$
3.  `h2`: $x + y + 3 = 0$
4.  `h3`: $(x - 3)^2 + y^2 = (x + 3)^2 + (y - 2)^2$

Our goal is to prove that $8x - y - 24 = 0$.

The proof demonstrates that the given hypotheses are contradictory. From a contradiction, any statement can be proven.

First, let's simplify hypothesis `h3` by expanding the squared terms:
$x^2 - 6x + 9 + y^2 = x^2 + 6x + 9 + y^2 - 4y + 4$

We can cancel $x^2$, $y^2$, and $9$ from both sides, which leaves:
$-6x = 6x - 4y + 4$

Rearranging the terms to one side gives us a new linear equation:
$12x - 4y + 4 = 0$

Dividing the entire equation by 4 simplifies it to:
$3x - y + 1 = 0$

Now, we have a system of three linear equations supposedly satisfied by `x` and `y`:
(1) $2x - y - 2 = 0$ (from `h1`)
(2) $x + y + 3 = 0$ (from `h2`)
(3) $3x - y + 1 = 0$ (from `h3`)

Let's solve for `x` and `y` using the first two equations. By adding equation (1) and (2), we can eliminate `y`:
$(2x - y - 2) + (x + y + 3) = 0$
$3x + 1 = 0$
$x = -1/3$

Now, we substitute $x = -1/3$ into equation (2) to find `y`:
$(-1/3) + y + 3 = 0$
$y + 8/3 = 0$
$y = -8/3$

So, the only possible values that can satisfy both `h1` and `h2` are $x = -1/3$ and $y = -8/3$. (Note that $x = -1/3$ also satisfies hypothesis `h`).

Next, we check if these values satisfy the third equation, which was derived from `h3`. We substitute $x = -1/3$ and $y = -8/3$ into $3x - y + 1 = 0$:
$3(-1/3) - (-8/3) + 1 = -1 + 8/3 + 1 = 8/3$

The equation requires this expression to be equal to 0, but we have found it to be $8/3$. This leads to the statement:
$8/3 = 0$

This is a clear contradiction. Since the initial hypotheses `h1`, `h2`, and `h3` together lead to a false statement, the set of hypotheses is inconsistent. In logic, from an inconsistent set of premises, any conclusion can be derived. This is known as the principle of explosion.

Therefore, the conclusion $8x - y - 24 = 0$ logically follows from the given contradictory hypotheses.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6. Draw a line through $P(3,0)$ such that the line segment $A B$ intercepted between the two lines $2 x-y-2=0$ and $x+y+3=0$ is exactly bisected by point $P$. Then the equation of this line is $\qquad$ . -/
theorem algebra_111048 {x y : ℝ} (h : x ≠ 0) (h1 : 2 * x - y - 2 = 0) (h2 : x + y + 3 = 0)
    (h3 : (x - 3) ^ 2 + y ^ 2 = (x + 3) ^ 2 + (y - 2) ^ 2) :
    8 * x - y - 24 = 0 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_111048 {x y : ℝ} (h : x ≠ 0) (h1 : 2 * x - y - 2 = 0) (h2 : x + y + 3 = 0)
    (h3 : (x - 3) ^ 2 + y ^ 2 = (x + 3) ^ 2 + (y - 2) ^ 2) :
    8 * x - y - 24 = 0 := by 
  nlinarith

soln_description:
6. Between the fifth and sixth stations, the passenger train meets 3 freight trains.
6.【Solution】A freight train is dispatched every 5 minutes, with a speed of 60 kilometers per hour, which is 1 kilometer per minute. Therefore, the distance between two consecutive freight trains is 5 kilometers.

The first freight train has been traveling for 1 hour before the passenger train departs, so the distance between the two trains is $7 \times (11-1) - 60 \times 1 = 10$ (kilometers),

The two trains meet after $\frac{10}{100+60} = \frac{1}{16}$ (hours),
meeting at a distance of $\frac{1}{16} \times 100 = \frac{25}{4}$ (kilometers) from the first station.
Since the distance between two consecutive freight trains is 5 kilometers, after the passenger train meets one freight train, it travels another $\frac{5}{100+60} \times 100 = \frac{25}{8}$ (kilometers),

before meeting the next freight train.
If A and B are two adjacent stations, then when the passenger train meets 3 freight trains between these two stations, the distance from the point where it meets the first freight train to point A should not exceed $7 - \frac{25}{8} \times 2 = \frac{3}{4}$ (kilometers).

Conversely, when this condition is met, the passenger train meets three freight trains between A and B. Suppose the passenger train meets the $(n+1)$-th freight train between stations A and B, and encounters two more freight trains between these two stations, then the passenger train has traveled $\frac{25}{4} + \frac{25}{8} n$ (kilometers) and the distance from the $(m+1)$-th station A is no more than $\frac{3}{4}$ kilometers, thus $\frac{25}{4} + \frac{25}{8} n - 7m \leq \frac{3}{4}$, which simplifies to $25(n+2) - 56m \leq 6$ (1)
Equation (1) indicates that a multiple of 25, when divided by 56, has a remainder $\leq 6$.

It is not difficult to verify that $25 \times 9 = 225 = 56 \times 4 + 1$, so the passenger train meets three freight trains between the 5th and 6th stations.

The next value that satisfies (1) is $25 \times 9 \times 2 = 56 \times 4 \times 2 + 2$, but at this point, $n+1 = 9 \times 2 - 1 = 17$. After the passenger train meets the $(n+1)$-th freight train, it can only meet one more freight train.

Therefore, the answer to this problem is: Between the 5th and 6th stations, the passenger train meets three freight trains. 【Note】If there are 19 or more freight trains, then between the 9th and 10th stations, the passenger train also meets three freight trains.
informal_statement: 6. On a two-way railway, there are 11 stations, each adjacent station being 7 kilometers apart. Starting at 7:00 AM, 18 freight trains are dispatched from the eleventh station in sequence, with one train every 5 minutes, all heading towards the first station at a speed of 60 kilometers per hour. At 8:00 AM, a passenger train is dispatched from the first station, heading towards the eleventh station at a speed of 100 kilometers per hour. Before reaching the terminal station, neither the freight trains nor the passenger train stop at any station. Question: Between which two adjacent stations can the passenger train meet 3 freight trains in succession?
informal_proof:
Let `t` be a real number. We are given two hypotheses:
1. `ht`: `t > 0`
2. `h`: `18 * (t / 5) = 100 * t + 3 * 7`

The goal is to prove that `t = 3`.

The proof proceeds by showing that the given hypotheses are mutually contradictory. In classical logic, any proposition can be derived from a contradiction (a principle known as *ex falso quodlibet*, or the principle of explosion). The Lean proof uses the `linarith` tactic, which is an automated tool for solving problems in linear arithmetic and can detect such contradictions.

Let's trace the reasoning that `linarith` performs. We start by simplifying the equation given in hypothesis `h`:
```
18 * (t / 5) = 100 * t + 3 * 7
```
The right side simplifies to `100 * t + 21`. The left side can be written as `(18/5) * t`. So the equation becomes:
```
(18/5) * t = 100 * t + 21
```
Now, we solve for `t` by isolating it. We subtract `100 * t` from both sides:
```
(18/5 - 100) * t = 21
```
Combining the terms on the left side:
```
(18/5 - 500/5) * t = 21
(-482/5) * t = 21
```
Finally, we solve for `t`:
```
t = 21 * (-5 / 482)
t = -105 / 482
```
The algebraic manipulation of hypothesis `h` forces `t` to be equal to `-105 / 482`. This value is negative.

However, hypothesis `ht` asserts that `t > 0`. We have thus derived a contradiction: `t` must be negative from `h`, but `t` must be positive from `ht`. Since the initial assumptions lead to a logical contradiction, they cannot both be true. From this inconsistent set of premises, any conclusion can be validly inferred.

Therefore, the statement `t = 3` follows. The `linarith` tactic in the formal proof automates this entire process of finding the contradiction and using it to prove the goal.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6. On a two-way railway, there are 11 stations, each adjacent station being 7 kilometers apart. Starting at 7:00 AM, 18 freight trains are dispatched from the eleventh station in sequence, with one train every 5 minutes, all heading towards the first station at a speed of 60 kilometers per hour. At 8:00 AM, a passenger train is dispatched from the first station, heading towards the eleventh station at a speed of 100 kilometers per hour. Before reaching the terminal station, neither the freight trains nor the passenger train stop at any station. Question: Between which two adjacent stations can the passenger train meet 3 freight trains in succession? -/
theorem algebra_248934 (t : ℝ) (ht : t > 0) (h : 18 * (t / 5) = 100 * t + 3 * 7) :
    t = 3 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_248934 (t : ℝ) (ht : t > 0) (h : 18 * (t / 5) = 100 * t + 3 * 7) :
    t = 3 := by 
  linarith

informal_statement:
Given a positive integer $n \geq 2$ and real numbers $a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n \in [0,1]$. Prove that there exist real numbers $b_1, b_2, \ldots, b_n \in \{0,1\}$, such that for all $1\leq k\leq l \leq n$ we have
$$\left| \sum_{i=k}^l (a_i-b_i)\right| \leq \frac{n}{n+1}.$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset Real

/- Given a positive integer $n \geq 2$ and real numbers $a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n \in [0,1]$. Prove that there exist real numbers $b_1, b_2, \ldots, b_n \in \{0,1\}$, such that for all $1\leq k\leq l \leq n$ we have
$$\left| \sum_{i=k}^l (a_i-b_i)\right| \leq \frac{n}{n+1}.$$ -/
theorem inequalities_38431
    (n : ℕ)
    (hn : 2 ≤ n)
    (a : ℕ → ℝ)
    (ha : ∀ i ∈ Icc 1 n, a i ∈ Set.Icc 0 1)
    : ∃ b : ℕ → ℝ, (∀ i ∈ Icc 1 n, b i = 0 ∨ b i = 1) ∧
    ∀ k ∈ Icc 1 n, ∀ l ∈ Icc 1 n, k ≤ l → |∑ i ∈ Icc k l, (a i - b i)| ≤ n / (n + 1 : ℝ) := by

soln_description:
To prove that \( x + y + z \ge 3 \) given that \( xyz + xy + yz + zx = 4 \) and \( x, y, z > 0 \), we can use the AM-GM inequality and some algebraic manipulations.

1. **Given Condition:**
   \[
   xyz + xy + yz + zx = 4
   \]

2. **Using AM-GM Inequality:**
   By the AM-GM inequality, we know that for any non-negative real numbers \(a, b, c\):
   \[
   \frac{a + b + c}{3} \ge \sqrt[3]{abc}
   \]
   Applying this to \(x, y, z\):
   \[
   \frac{x + y + z}{3} \ge \sqrt[3]{xyz}
   \]
   Therefore:
   \[
   x + y + z \ge 3 \sqrt[3]{xyz}
   \]

3. **Relating \(xyz\) to the Given Condition:**
   We need to relate \(xyz\) to the given condition \(xyz + xy + yz + zx = 4\). Let's denote \(x + y + z = t\) and \(xy + yz + zx = u\). From the given condition:
   \[
   xyz + u = 4
   \]
   Since \(u \ge 3\sqrt[3]{xyz}\) by AM-GM, we can write:
   \[
   xyz + 3\sqrt[3]{xyz} \le 4
   \]

4. **Analyzing the Cubic Equation:**
   Let \(a = \sqrt[3]{xyz}\). Then:
   \[
   a^3 + 3a \le 4
   \]
   We need to find the maximum value of \(a\) that satisfies this inequality. Consider the function:
   \[
   f(a) = a^3 + 3a
   \]
   We need to solve:
   \[
   a^3 + 3a = 4
   \]
   By trial or solving the cubic equation, we find that \(a = 1\) satisfies this equation:
   \[
   1^3 + 3 \cdot 1 = 4
   \]
   Therefore, \(a = \sqrt[3]{xyz} \le 1\).

5. **Conclusion:**
   Since \(a = \sqrt[3]{xyz} \le 1\), we have:
   \[
   x + y + z \ge 3 \sqrt[3]{xyz} \ge 3 \cdot 1 = 3
   \]
   Thus, we have shown that:
   \[
   x + y + z \ge 3
   \]
   \(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: Let $x, y, z > 0$ be real numbers such that $xyz + xy + yz + zx = 4$. Prove that $x + y + z  \ge 3$.
informal_proof:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers satisfying the equation $xyz + xy + yz + zx = 4$. We want to prove that $x + y + z \ge 3$.

The proof proceeds by contradiction, employing algebraic reasoning. We assume the negation of our goal, which is $x + y + z < 3$. The aim is to show that this assumption, in conjunction with the given conditions, leads to a logical inconsistency.

The proof relies on combining our hypothesis and assumption with several fundamental inequalities derived from the properties of real numbers. Specifically, we use the following facts:

1.  The square of any real number is non-negative. This gives us the inequalities:
    - $(x - y)^2 \ge 0$
    - $(y - z)^2 \ge 0$
    - $(z - x)^2 \ge 0$
    - $(x - 2)^2 \ge 0$
    - $(y - 2)^2 \ge 0$
    - $(z - 2)^2 \ge 0$

2.  The product of positive numbers is positive. Since we are given $x > 0$, $y > 0$, and $z > 0$, we have:
    - $xy > 0$
    - $xz > 0$
    - $yz > 0$

The core of the proof consists of an algorithm (`nlinarith`) that takes all these statements as input:
- **Equality:** $xyz + xy + yz + zx - 4 = 0$
- **Assumed Inequality:** $3 - (x + y + z) > 0$
- **Known Inequalities:** The list of non-negative squares and positive products mentioned above.

This algorithm systematically manipulates these polynomial expressions. It seeks to find a combination of them—for instance, by multiplying them by non-negative polynomials and summing the results—to produce an expression that is algebraically proven to be both non-negative and strictly negative. This results in a contradiction, such as deriving that $0 > c$ for some positive constant $c$.

Since the system of equations and inequalities formed by the hypotheses and the negation of the conclusion is unsatisfiable, our initial assumption ($x + y + z < 3$) must be false. Therefore, we conclude that its negation, $x + y + z \ge 3$, must be true.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $x, y, z > 0$ be real numbers such that $xyz + xy + yz + zx = 4$. Prove that $x + y + z  \ge 3$. -/
theorem inequalities_92020 (x y z : ℝ) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) (hz : 0 < z) (h : x * y * z + x * y + y * z + z * x = 4) : 3 ≤ x + y + z:= by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_92020 (x y z : ℝ) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) (hz : 0 < z) (h : x * y * z + x * y + y * z + z * x = 4) : 3 ≤ x + y + z:= by
  nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - y), sq_nonneg (y - z), sq_nonneg (z - x),
          sq_nonneg (x - 2), sq_nonneg (y - 2), sq_nonneg (z - 2),
          mul_pos hx hy, mul_pos hx hz, mul_pos hy hz
]

informal_statement:
1. Let $a_{n}=7^{n}+9^{n}\left(n \in \mathbf{N}_{+}\right)$. Then the remainder when $a_{2008}$ is divided by 64 is ( ).
(A) 0
(B) 2
(C) 16
(D) 22
informal_proof:
We want to find the remainder when $a_{2008}$ is divided by 64.

First, by the definition of the sequence $a_n = 7^n + 9^n$, we substitute $n = 2008$ to get the expression:
$$a_{2008} = 7^{2008} + 9^{2008}$$
Our goal is to compute the value of this expression modulo 64.

To simplify the calculation, we can express the bases, 7 and 9, in terms of 8:
$$7 = 8 - 1$$
$$9 = 8 + 1$$
Substituting these into our expression gives:
$$a_{2008} = (8 - 1)^{2008} + (8 + 1)^{2008}$$
We can now apply the binomial theorem to each term. The binomial expansion of $(x+y)^n$ is $\sum_{k=0}^{n} \binom{n}{k} x^{n-k} y^k$.

For the first term, $(8 - 1)^{2008}$:
$$(8 - 1)^{2008} = \binom{2008}{0}8^{2008}(-1)^0 + \binom{2008}{1}8^{2007}(-1)^1 + \dots + \binom{2008}{2006}8^2(-1)^{2006} + \binom{2008}{2007}8^1(-1)^{2007} + \binom{2008}{2008}8^0(-1)^{2008}$$
When we consider this expansion modulo 64, we observe that any term containing $8^k$ for $k \ge 2$ is a multiple of $8^2 = 64$ and is therefore congruent to 0 modulo 64. Thus, we only need to consider the last two terms of the expansion (for $k=2007$ and $k=2008$):
$$(8 - 1)^{2008} \equiv \binom{2008}{2007} \cdot 8^1 \cdot (-1)^{2007} + \binom{2008}{2008} \cdot 8^0 \cdot (-1)^{2008} \pmod{64}$$
$$(8 - 1)^{2008} \equiv 2008 \cdot 8 \cdot (-1) + 1 \cdot 1 \cdot 1 \pmod{64}$$
$$(8 - 1)^{2008} \equiv -2008 \cdot 8 + 1 \pmod{64}$$

For the second term, $(8 + 1)^{2008}$:
$$(8 + 1)^{2008} = \binom{2008}{0}8^{2008}(1)^0 + \dots + \binom{2008}{2006}8^2(1)^{2006} + \binom{2008}{2007}8^1(1)^{2007} + \binom{2008}{2008}8^0(1)^{2008}$$
Similarly, all terms except the last two are multiples of 64.
$$(8 + 1)^{2008} \equiv \binom{2008}{2007} \cdot 8^1 \cdot 1^{2007} + \binom{2008}{2008} \cdot 8^0 \cdot 1^{2008} \pmod{64}$$
$$(8 + 1)^{2008} \equiv 2008 \cdot 8 \cdot 1 + 1 \cdot 1 \cdot 1 \pmod{64}$$
$$(8 + 1)^{2008} \equiv 2008 \cdot 8 + 1 \pmod{64}$$

Now, we sum the two results:
$$a_{2008} \equiv (-2008 \cdot 8 + 1) + (2008 \cdot 8 + 1) \pmod{64}$$
The terms involving $2008 \cdot 8$ cancel each other out:
$$a_{2008} \equiv 1 + 1 \pmod{64}$$
$$a_{2008} \equiv 2 \pmod{64}$$

Thus, the remainder when $a_{2008}$ is divided by 64 is 2.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def a (n : ℕ) := 7 ^ n + 9 ^ n

/- 1. Let $a_{n}=7^{n}+9^{n}\left(n \in \mathbf{N}_{+}\right)$. Then the remainder when $a_{2008}$ is divided by 64 is ( ).
(A) 0
(B) 2
(C) 16
(D) 22 -/
theorem number_theory_320567 : a 2008 % 64 = 2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

def a (n : ℕ) := 7 ^ n + 9 ^ n

theorem number_theory_320567 : a 2008 % 64 = 2 := by
  unfold a
  norm_num

soln_description:
Solution: By the definition of like radicals, we have
$3 x+y=y+6$, which gives $x=2$.
$\because$ The root index $6+y$ is even,
$\therefore$ the radicand $4-y$ and $6+y$ are both non-negative, i.e., $4-y \geqslant 0$, and $6+y \geqslant 0$.
Solving this, we get $-6 \leqslant y \leqslant 4$.
Thus, the even number $y=-6,-4,-2,0,2,4$.
However, when $y=-6$, the root index $y+6$ is zero, making the radical expression meaningless; when $y=-4,-2,0,4$, at least one of the radicals is not in its simplest form.
Therefore, $y=2$. The correct choice is (B).
informal_statement:
Example 1 If the simplest radical expressions $\sqrt[3 x+y]{2 x-y}$ and $\sqrt[y+6]{4 x+y-2}$ are of the same degree, and $y$ is an even number, then the sum of all possible values of $y$ is ( ).
(A) 0
(B) 2
(C) 4
(D) 6
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 1 If the simplest radical expressions $\sqrt[3 x+y]{2 x-y}$ and $\sqrt[y+6]{4 x+y-2}$ are of the same degree, and $y$ is an even number, then the sum of all possible values of $y$ is ( ).
(A) 0
(B) 2
(C) 4
(D) 6 -/
theorem algebra_309932 (y : ℤ) (hy : Even y) :
    ∃ x, (2 * x - y) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (3 * x + y)) =
    (4 * x + y - 2) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (y + 6)) ↔ y = 2 := by

soln_description:
7. $\left\{\begin{array}{l}a=3 \\ b=2\end{array}\right.$ Detailed explanation: $a>b \geqslant 1$, from the conditions we get $a^{a}>a^{a-1} \cdot b^{b-1} \Rightarrow a>b^{b-1}$, thus we have $a \geqslant b^{b-1}+1$, so $a \cdot b \geqslant b^{b}+b$, which means $b^{b} \leqslant a b-b$, and from the given conditions and the above results we get
$a^{a-1} \cdot b^{b-1}+a+b=a^{a}-b^{b} \geqslant a^{a}-(a b-b)=a^{a}-a b+b$,
$\therefore a+a b \geqslant a^{a-1}\left(a-b^{b-1}\right)$, thus $a^{2}=a+a(a-1) \geqslant a+a b \geqslant a^{a-1}\left(a-b^{b-1}\right) \geqslant a^{a-1}$,
which means $1 \geqslant a^{a-3}$, so $2 \leqslant a \leqslant 3$, it is easy to see: when $a=2$, we must have $b=1$, but this does not meet the problem's conditions; when $a=3$, $b^{b}<3$, so $b=2$ (since $b=1$ does not meet the problem's conditions), thus the positive integer solution to this problem is $\left\{\begin{array}{l}a=3 \\ b=2\end{array}\right.$.
informal_statement: 7. All positive integer pairs $(a, b)$ that satisfy the condition $a^{a}-b^{b}=a^{a-1} \cdot b^{b-1}+a+b$ are
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7. All positive integer pairs $(a, b)$ that satisfy the condition $a^{a}-b^{b}=a^{a-1} \cdot b^{b-1}+a+b$ are -/
theorem algebra_285466 (a b : ℕ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b)
    (h : a^a - b^b = a^(a-1) * b^(b-1) + a + b) :
    a = 3 ∧ b = 2 := by

soln_description:
Proof: When $n=1$, by Lemma 10, we know that this lemma holds. Now let $n \geqslant 2$. The multiples of $p_{1}$ not greater than $a$ are
$$p_{1}, 2 p_{1}, \cdots, \frac{a}{p_{1}} p_{1}$$

There are $\frac{a}{p_{1}}$ such numbers. Therefore, the number of positive integers not greater than $a$ and coprime with $p_{1}$ is
$$a-\frac{a}{p_{1}}=a\left(1-\frac{1}{p_{1}}\right)$$

The multiples of $p_{2}$ not greater than $a$ are
$$p_{2}, 2 p_{2}, 3 p_{2}, \cdots, \frac{a}{p_{2}} p_{2}$$

There are $\frac{a}{p_{2}}$ such numbers. However, among $p_{2}, 2 p_{2}, 3 p_{2}, \cdots, \frac{a}{p_{2}} p_{2}$, there are multiples of $p_{1}$, i.e.,
$$p_{1} p_{2}, 2 p_{1} p_{2}, 3 p_{1} p_{2}, \cdots, \frac{a}{p_{1} p_{2}} p_{1} p_{2}$$

There are $\frac{a}{p_{1} p_{2}}$ such numbers. Therefore, the number of positive integers not greater than $a$ that are multiples of $p_{2}$ but not multiples of $p_{1}$ is
$$\frac{a}{p_{2}}-\frac{a}{p_{1} p_{2}}=\frac{a}{p_{2}}\left(1-\frac{1}{p_{1}}\right)$$

Therefore, the number of positive integers not greater than $a$ and coprime with both $p_{1}$ and $p_{2}$ is
$$a\left(1-\frac{1}{p_{1}}\right)-\frac{a}{p_{2}}\left(1-\frac{1}{p_{1}}\right)=a\left(1-\frac{1}{p_{1}}\right)\left(1-\frac{1}{p_{2}}\right)$$

When $n=2$, by $a=p_{1}^{a_{1}} p_{2}^{a_{2}}$ and equation (25), we have
$$\varphi(a)=p_{1}^{a_{1}-1}\left(p_{1}-1\right) p_{2}^{a_{2}-1}\left(p_{2}-1\right)$$

Therefore, the lemma holds when $n=2$. Now let $n \geqslant 3$. The multiples of $p_{3}$ not greater than $a$ are
$$p_{3}, 2 p_{3}, 3 p_{3}, \cdots, \frac{a}{p_{3}} p_{3}$$

There are $\frac{a}{p_{3}}$ such numbers. However, among $p_{3}, 2 p_{3}, 3 p_{3}, \cdots, \frac{a}{p_{3}} p_{3}$, there are multiples of $p_{1}$, i.e.,
$$p_{1} p_{3}, 2 p_{1} p_{3}, \cdots, \frac{a}{p_{1} p_{3}} p_{1} p_{3}$$

There are $\frac{a}{p_{1} p_{3}}$ such numbers. Among $p_{3}, 2 p_{3}, 3 p_{3}, \cdots, \frac{a}{p_{3}} p_{3}$, there are multiples of $p_{2}$, i.e.,
$$p_{2} p_{3}, 2 p_{2} p_{3}, \cdots, \frac{a}{p_{2} p_{3}} p_{2} p_{3}$$

There are $\frac{a}{p_{2} p_{3}}$ such numbers. Among $p_{1} p_{3}, 2 p_{1} p_{3}, \cdots, \frac{a}{p_{1} p_{3}} p_{1} p_{3}$, there are multiples of $p_{2}$, i.e.,
$$p_{1} p_{2} p_{3}, 2 p_{1} p_{2} p_{3}, \cdots, \frac{a}{p_{1} p_{2} p_{3}} p_{1} p_{2} p_{3},$$

There are $\frac{a}{p_{1} p_{2} p_{3}}$ such numbers. Among $p_{2} p_{3}, 2 p_{2} p_{3}, \cdots, \frac{a}{p_{2} p_{3}} p_{2} p_{3}$, there are multiples of $p_{1}$, i.e.,
$$p_{1} p_{2} p_{3}, 2 p_{1} p_{2} p_{3}, \cdots, \frac{a}{p_{1} p_{2} p_{3}} p_{1} p_{2} p_{3}$$

There are $\frac{a}{p_{1} p_{2} p_{3}}$ such numbers. Therefore, the number of positive integers not greater than $a$ that are multiples of $p_{3}$ and coprime with both $p_{1}$ and $p_{2}$ is
$$\frac{a}{p_{3}}-\frac{a}{p_{1} p_{3}}-\frac{a}{p_{2} p_{3}}+\frac{a}{p_{1} p_{2} p_{3}}=\frac{a}{p_{3}}\left(1-\frac{1}{p_{1}}\right)\left(1-\frac{1}{p_{2}}\right)$$

By equations (25) and (26), the number of positive integers not greater than $a$ and coprime with $p_{1}, p_{2}, p_{3}$ is
$$\begin{array}{l}
a\left(1-\frac{1}{p_{1}}\right)\left(1-\frac{1}{p_{2}}\right)-\frac{a}{p_{3}}\left(1-\frac{1}{p_{1}}\right)\left(1-\frac{1}{p_{2}}\right) \\
\quad=a\left(1-\frac{1}{p_{1}}\right)\left(1-\frac{1}{p_{2}}\right)\left(1-\frac{1}{p_{3}}\right)
\end{array}$$

When $n=3$, by $a=p_{1}^{\alpha_{1}} p_{2}^{\alpha_{2}}+p_{3}^{a_{3}}$ and equation (27), we have
$$\varphi(a)=p_{1}^{a_{1}-1}\left(p_{1}-1\right) p_{2}^{a_{2}-1}\left(p_{2}-1\right) p_{3}^{a_{3}-1}\left(p_{3}-1\right)$$

Therefore, the lemma holds when $n=3$. When $n \geqslant 4$, the same method can be applied. We will eventually get that the number of positive integers not greater than $a$ and coprime with $p_{1}, p_{2}, \cdots, p_{n}$ (i.e., the number of positive integers not greater than $a$ and coprime with $a$) is
$$a\left(1-\frac{1}{p_{1}}\right)\left(1-\frac{1}{p_{2}}\right) \cdots\left(1-\frac{1}{p_{n}}\right)$$

That is, $\varphi(a)=p_{1}^{a_{1}-1}\left(p_{1}-1\right) \cdots p_{n}^{a_{n}-1}\left(p_{n}-1\right)$.
informal_statement:
Lemma 14 If $a=p_{1}^{a_{i}} \cdots p_{n}^{a_{n}}$, where $p_{1}, \cdots, p_{n}$ are all primes and $\alpha_{1}, \cdots, \alpha_{n}$ are all positive integers, then we have
$$\varphi(a)=p_{1}^{a_{1}-1}\left(p_{1}-1\right) \cdots p_{n}^{a_{n}-1}\left(p_{n}-1\right)$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Lemma 14 If $a=p_{1}^{a_{i}} \cdots p_{n}^{a_{n}}$, where $p_{1}, \cdots, p_{n}$ are all primes and $\alpha_{1}, \cdots, \alpha_{n}$ are all positive integers, then we have
$$\varphi(a)=p_{1}^{a_{1}-1}\left(p_{1}-1\right) \cdots p_{n}^{a_{n}-1}\left(p_{n}-1\right)$$ -/
theorem number_theory_7055 (a : ℕ) (ha : a ≠ 0) (p : Finset ℕ)
    (hp : ∀ i ∈ p, Nat.Prime i) (a' : ℕ → ℕ) (ha' : ∀ i ∈ p, a' i > 0)
    (h : a = ∏ i ∈ p, i ^ a' i) :
    Nat.totient a = ∏ i ∈ p, (i ^ (a' i - 1)) * (i - 1) := by

soln_description:
Suppose by contradiction that $P$ has only real roots. The leading coefficient of $P$ is 1 or -1, so by replacing $P$ with $-P$ if necessary, we can assume $P$ is monic, and write

$$
P(x)=\left(x-r_{1}\right) \ldots\left(x-r_{n}\right)=x^{n}+a_{n-1} x^{n-1}+\ldots+a_{1} x+a_{0} .
$$

By the relations between coefficients and roots, we have

$$
a_{n-1}=r_{1}+r_{2}+\ldots+r_{n}
$$

$$
a_{n-2}=\sum_{1 \leq i<j \leq n} r_{i} r_{j}
$$

We then have

$$
\left(a_{n-1}\right)^{2}-2 a_{n-2}=r_{1}^{2}+\ldots+r_{n}^{2}
$$

Since the $r_{i}$ are real, the $r_{i}^{2}$ are positive, and we can apply the arithmetic-geometric mean inequality to obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
r_{1}^{2}+\ldots+r_{n}^{2} & \geq n \sqrt[n]{\left(r_{1} \ldots r_{n}\right)^{2}} \\
= & n \sqrt[n]{a_{0}^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $P(0) \neq 0, a_{0} \neq 0$ and thus $a_{0}^{2}=1$, we have

$$
\left(a_{n-1}\right)^{2}-2 a_{n-2} \geq n
$$

However, $a_{n-1}^{2} \leq 1$ and $-2 a_{n-2} \leq 2$, which gives, upon summing and substituting, $3 \geq n$, a contradiction.
informal_statement: Let $P$ be a polynomial of degree $n \geq 4$ with coefficients in $\{-1,0,1\}$ and such that $P(0) \neq 0$. Show that $P$ has at least one non-real root.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $P$ be a polynomial of degree $n \geq 4$ with coefficients in $\{-1,0,1\}$ and such that $P(0) \neq 0$. Show that $P$ has at least one non-real root. -/
theorem algebra_163017 {P : Polynomial ℂ} (hP : P.degree ≥ 4)
    (hP1 : ∀ n ∈ Finset.range (P.natDegree + 1), P.coeff n = -1 ∨ P.coeff n = 0 ∨ P.coeff n = 1)
    (hP2 : P.eval 0 ≠ 0) :
    ∃ z : ℂ, z ∈ P.roots ∧ ¬(z.im = 0 ∧ z.re ≠ 0) := by

soln_description:
Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{(2 n+1)^{2}-(n+1)^{2}}{n^{2}+n+1}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{4 n^{2}+4 n+1-n^{2}-2 n-1}{n^{2}+n+1}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\frac{1}{n^{2}}\left(3 n^{2}+2 n\right)}{\frac{1}{n^{2}}\left(n^{2}+n+1\right)}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{3+\frac{2}{n}}{1+\frac{1}{n}+\frac{1}{n^{2}}}=\frac{3+0}{1+0+0}=3
\end{aligned}
$$
